=\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t=20\n\n<p><font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"3"><strong>First National Power Corp. to Introduce Proprietary =\nTechnology to European Markets. Survey Concludes \' ... (Electricity) =\nEnough to Power Over 150 Million Homes.\'</strong></font></p>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"1">Wednesday March 3, 4:08 pm ET</font></p> =20\n\n<p>Further to Our Press Release of March 2nd, 2004 \' ... Wind is the =\nWorld\'s Fastest-Growing Energy Source - Wind Energy Could Power Every =\nHome in Europe by 2020\' </p>\n\n\n<p>FOX ISLAND, Wash., March 3 /PRNewswire/ -- First National Power Corp =\n(OTC Bulletin Board: FNPR - News) from an Article published, LONDON, =\nMarch 1 /CNW/ -- Every home in Europe could be powered by clean green =\noffshore wind energy, according to a new report released by =\ninternational energy experts. Researchers at the respected Garrad Hassan =\ngroup examined wind speeds, sea depths, economic infrastructure and =\nadvancements in offshore wind technology. They concluded that as many as =\n50,000 turbines could be built in European seas, generating the =\nequivalent of 720 billion domestic units of electricity -- enough to =\npower well over 150 million homes.</p>\n<p>The report -- entitled "Sea Wind Europe" -- predicts the European =\nwind industry is about to expand hugely, with major construction =\nprojects off countries including Germany, the UK, the Netherlands, =\nFrance and Spain. It says wind could supply almost a third of all =\nEurope\'s electricity needs including industry, service sector and =\ndomestic needs -- a comparable amount to that currently supplied by the =\nentire EU nuclear industry.</p>=20\n\n   <p>The researchers go on to say that by 2020 wind power could:<br>\n    -- create up to 3 million jobs across Europe<br>\n    -- rejuvenate declining industries and depressed industrial =\nareas<br>\n    -- create a multi-million euro renewable energy market<br>\n    -- set Europe on the road to a completely clean energy supply system =\nthat<br>\n       &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;is safe, secure and environmentally =\nsustainable<br>\n    -- provide cheaper electricity than both coal and nuclear power.<br>\n   </p>\n\n<p>"Canada holds the bulk of North American wind potential and yet we\'re =\nlagging behind in terms of both wind production and investment," said =\nSteven Guilbeault from Greenpeace. "The Canadian government is missing a =\ngreat opportunity to be a leader in the field of renewable energy, =\ninstead of which it continues to favor polluting fossil fuels and =\nnuclear energy."</p>\n\n<p>"World leaders are facing the massive twin problems of energy =\nsecurity and climate change. This report shows that wind farms at sea, =\nand on land, can be the backbone of the world\'s clean energy future, =\nputting an end to the lie that renewable energy can\'t deliver on a large =\nscale. What is true for Europe could also be true for Canada if Paul =\nMartin could show the leadership that is required to make it happen," =\nGuilbeault added.</p>\n\n<p>The report can be found at <a =\nhref=3D"http://click1.upper-web-side.com/sp/t.pl?id=3D17816:53305368">htt=\np://www.greenpeace.org.uk/seawindeurope.htm</a></p>\n\n<p>About First National Power\n\nFirst National Power Corporation is a fully reporting Public Corporation =\nlisted on the NASDAQ Over-the-Counter Bulletin Board (OTC/BB) under the =\ntrading symbol FNPR (formerly CSNI). The FNPR Green Energy Power =\nGeneration business model is designed to develop and implement cutting =\nedge technology not formerly utilized in the electrical power generation =\nindustry and current technology configurations in new and exciting =\ncommercial applications, as exampled by the GREEN OASIS project under =\ncurrent development. <a =\nhref=3D"http://click1.upper-web-side.com/sp/t.pl?id=3D17817:53305368">htt=\np://www.firstnationalpower.com</a></p>\n\n<p>"Safe Harbor" Statement Under The Private Securities Litigation =\nReform Act of 1995: The statements in the press release that relate to =\nthe company\'s expectations with regard to the future impact on the =\ncompany\'s results from new products in development are forward-looking =\nstatements, within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation =\nReform Act of 1995. Since this information may contain statements that =\ninvolve risk and uncertainties and are subject to change at any time, =\nthe company\'s actual results may differ materially from expected =\nresults.</p>=20\n\n\n<p>Source: Wannigan Capital Corp</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font>\n<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2"><strong></strong></font></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n\t<table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">The =\nInventor</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>Mr. Alvin Snaper has served as a Senior Consultant to other major =\ncorporations and organizations, including IBM, General Foods, NASA, =\nBoeing, Gillette, Singer, U.S. Air Force, Rocketdyne, General Motors, =\nLockheed Aircraft, Sanyo, Philips, Gulf Western, Union Carbide, etc.   =\nSome of his inventions and commercial products include the IBM Selectric =\nType Ball, Tang, the NASA Apollo Photo- Pack, Coating Process for =\nGillette Razor Blades, and the Electrostatic Painting Process & System =\nfor Auto Components Assemblies for General Motors, to name a few. Mr. =\nAlvin Snaper holds the single honor and individual distinction of being =\nrecognized three times with \'Best Patent of the Year\' award by Design =\nNews magazine, and is the author of numerous technical and scientific =\npapers.</p>\n\t\t\t\t <p><font color=3D"#009966" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2">Market Size and Market Growth</font></p>\n                 <p>Record Growth For Global Wind Power In 2002 (2003 =\nfigures not available yet) increased by 28%, wind technology worth $7.3 =\nBillion Dollars installed last year A record 6,868 megawatts (MW) of new =\nwind power capacity was installed worldwide in 2002, increasing =\ngenerating capacity by 28% last year, according to new figures released =\nfrom the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) and European Wind =\nEnergy Association (EWEA). Wind power technology worth &#8364;6.8 =\nbillion ($7.3 billion) was installed globally in 2002, driving total =\nwind power installation to over 31,000 Megawatts (MW), enough to power =\n7.5 million average American homes (16 million average European =\nhomes).</p>\n                 <p>Global wind power capacity has quadrupled over the =\npast five years, growing from 7,600 MW at the end of 1997 to more than =\n31,000 MW at the end of 2002 - an increase of over 23,000 MW. Wind is =\nthe world\'s fastest-growing energy source, with installed generating =\ncapacity increasing by an average 32% annually for the last five years =\n(1998-2002). 93% of the additional wind power capacity installed in 2002 =\nwas in Europe and the United States, and worldwide 90% of capacity is =\nfound in those two regions.</p>\n                 <p>&quot;Wind energy grew by 10% in the United States =\nin 2002, a good performance given the poor state of the U.S. energy =\nmarket and the stop-and-go-and-stop-again policy signals directed at our =\nindustry,&quot; said AWEA executive director Randall Swisher. &quot;With =\nsteady supportive policies, wind power could grow at a sustained pace =\ncloser to that of Europe, and provide well over 6% of U.S. electricity =\nby 2020.&quot;</p>\n                 <p>Over 75% of the world\'s wind power is generated in =\nEurope, and the region again fuelled the bulk of last year\'s growth =\n&#8212; an achievement that flows from a steady commitment to developing =\nrenewable sources of energy. A total of 5,871 MW &#8212; worth =\n&#8364;5.8 billion ($6.2 billion) &#8212; was installed in the E.U =\ncountries. Total wind power capacity in the region grew 33% to 23,056 =\nMW. The United States added 410 MW (a 10% increase), and Canada about 40 =\nMW. Spain now generates more wind power than the United States.</p>\n                 <p>The countries with most wind power capacity are =\nGermany - by far the largest, with just over 12,000 MW - followed by =\nSpain, the United States, Denmark, and India.</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong>\n\t\t\t\t</font></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n\t <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2">Summary</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>When most people think of Windmills, they probably think of =\nHolland and Tulips. We\'re willing to bet that most people do not realize =\nthat the Architectural Company that won the right to design the New =\nWorld Trade Center in New York, envisions powering part of the building =\nusing this very technology.</p>\n\t\t\t\t<p>FNPR has bought the rights to inventor Alvin Snaper\'s propless =\nwind power generator - in other words, a windmill with no propellers. =\nSnaper, who among other things, invented the IBM Selectric typewriter =\nball, as well as, Tang, Orange Flavored Drink, for General Foods will =\nhead up FNPR\'s Green Power Generation technical advisory team. </p>\n\t\t\t\t<p>This technology breakthrough will allow FNPR to enter a huge =\nMulti- Billion Dollar Untapped Electricity Market, by turning commercial =\nand residential high-rise buildings into self-generating energy systems =\nwith the capacity to sell surplus power back onto the grid. This market =\nis currently inaccessible to propeller driven turbines.</p>\n\t\t\t\t<p>FNPR is new to the Market, creating a unique business model, and =\nlooking to grow rapidly.</p>\n\t\t\t\t<p>According to the CEO, look for exciting new development\'s in the =\nnear future, ?These projects reflect the expansion of management\'s =\ncommitment to a world clean environment and the demand for a clean =\naffordable and renewable energy source. We will soon be announcing other =\nstrategic alliances.</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font> </td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td bgcolor=3D"#009966"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n=09\n</td>\n  </tr>\n  <tr>\n  <td>\n  <table cellpadding=3D"10" border=3D"0" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n  \t<tr>\n\t        <TD bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"1">=20\n             Important Disclaimer and Information:\n\n                 <br>\n                 <br>\n             Verify all claims and do your own due diligence. cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t=09\n\t\t\t\t<p><font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"3" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>Telecommunication Products Acquires 20% Interest of =\nB2 Networks, LLC</strong></font><br>\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"1" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">\n\t\t\t\tThursday April 29, 5:09 pm ET</font> </p>\n<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">\n\n<p>BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.&#8212;(BUSINESS WIRE)&#8212;April 29, =\n2004&#8212;Telecommunication Products, Inc. (OTCBB:TCPD &#8212; News; =\n"Telpro"), a provider of Pay-per-View and Digital Satellite Services, =\nannounced today that it has acquired a 20 percent interest in B2 =\nNetworks, LLC, a premier provider of international broadband video =\nnetworks, management, distribution and billing systems. Pursuant to a =\npurchase agreement, Telpro has purchased 20% of B2 Networks, LLC in =\nexchange for cash and shares of Telpro stock. In addition, the contract =\nincludes an option to further increase this investment up to 49% of =\ntotal outstanding issued shares in B2 Networks. In partnership with B2 =\nNetworks, Telpro previously announced their plans to market and deliver =\ndigital entertainment and broadband services under the banner name =\nHotellinktv.com to its rapidly expanding base of more than 8,000 =\nrooms.</p>=20\n\n<p>Telpro and B2 Networks will create a strategic position within the =\nHospitality and Hotel industry to deliver services that capitalize on B2 =\nNetworks\' "state of the art" digital delivery systems and data centers =\nto Telpro customers.</p>=20\n\n<p>The alliance will offer and supply wireless point to point (P2P) =\nlocal loop internet connections to hospitality and hotel properties upon =\nexisting internal property broadband networks. These wireless =\nconnections will provide the new alliance with a new, expanded digital =\nnetwork for the supply of new services and entertainment to the hotel =\nguests using their lap top computers in the rooms.</p>=20\n\n<p>Secondly, this new digital network access to the hotel rooms will =\nallow the alliance to deploy the B2 Digital TV Set Top box that will =\nallow guests to order services such as live sports, events and movies =\nvia a handheld remote on the in room televisions.</p>=20\n\n<p>B2 Networks and Telpro will capitalize on their existing content and =\nentertainment distribution contracts to deliver in room entertainment =\nand services from movies to live sporting events, shows and distinct =\ngenres of entertainment.</p>=20\n\n<p>B2 Networks provides Telpro with full data center facilities and a =\nfully customized digital content encryption and delivery solution that =\ninclude Transaction Billing, Automated Collections Processing, Digital =\nContent Management, Full Transaction Audit Trail and Hardware & Software =\nSystems Management. B2 Networks also offers Telpro access to their =\ndistribution rights to over 25,000 hours of distinct genres of movies =\nand entertainment that include broadcasts of live sporting events and =\nshows, on-demand movies, archived sports and genre specific films.</p>=20\n\n<p>Robert Russell, CEO of Telpro, stated, "Our investment in B2 Networks =\nrepresents our confidence in the company and their ability to deliver =\noperational and marketing synergies to Telpro. Telpro will benefit from =\nB2\'s strengths in digital network infrastructure, content distribution =\nrights, which are scalable, cost-control systems, and can help us =\nrapidly expand our services and content to hotel rooms the United =\nStates." </p>\n\n<p>About B2 Networks (LLC) </p>\n\n<p>B2 Networks is a premier provider of reliable, scalable and secure =\ninternational broadband video networks, management, distribution and =\nbilling systems. B2\'s core networks, data centers and systems are =\ncurrently in use to distribute entertainment, sports and live events to =\ncomputer and television screens in hotels and homes around the world. B2 =\nmanages and owns the digital distribution rights to distinct genres of =\nentertainment, sports and television properties and works with clients =\nsuch as Digicast, USA Gymnastics, Lennox Lewis, Oregon State University, =\nLas Vegas Wranglers, Guest DSL and Telecommunication Products, Inc. For =\nmore information, visit www.b2now.com.</p>=20\n\n<p>About Telecommunication Products, Inc.</p>=20\n\n<p>Telecommunication Products, Inc. ("Telpro"), is a provider of =\nvideo-on-demand and pay-per-view services to the hospitality industry. =\nTelpro also currently markets high-speed Internet access products, =\nincluding high-end WiFi (wireless fidelity). Telpro is committed to =\ndelivering the next generation of interactive communication services to =\nits growing database of clients. For additional information, please see =\nwww.tellapro.com or for Investor Relations go to: =\nhttp://www.otcfn.com/tcpd.</p>=20\n\n<p>This press release contains forward-looking statements, involving =\nrisks and uncertainties including statements regarding the Company\'s =\nfinancial performance. Such statements are based on management\'s current =\nexpectations and are subject to certain factors, risks and uncertainties =\nthat may cause actual results, events and performance to differ =\nmaterially from those referred to or implied by such statements. In =\naddition, actual future results may differ materially from those =\nanticipated, depending on a variety of factors which include, but are =\nnot limited to, our ability to leverage our technology, manage our =\ngrowth, protect our intellectual property rights, attract new customers =\nand general economic conditions affecting consumer spending, including =\nuncertainties relating to global political conditions, such as terrorism =\nand the conflict with Iraq. Information with respect to important =\nfactors that should be considered is contained in the Company\'s Annual =\nReport on Form 10-KSB as filed with the Securities and Exchange =\nCommission. Readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these =\nforward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date hereof. The =\nCompany does not intend to update any of the forward-looking statements =\nafter the date of this release to conform these statements to actual =\nresults or to changes in its expectations, except as may be required by =\nlaw. </p>\n\n<p>Contact: <br><br>\n     OTC Financial Network<br>\n     Investor Relations:<br>\n     Geoffrey J. Eiten, 781-444-6100 ext. 613<br>\n     <a href=3D"mailto:geiten@otcfn.com">geiten@otcfn.com</a><br>\n     or<br>\n     B2 Networks<br>\n     Greg P. Bell, 702-940-7905\n</p>\n\n<p>Source: Telecommunication Products, Inc.</p>\n\n</font></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td bgcolor=3D"#009966"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/dailydouble/images/clear.g=\nif" height=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/dailydouble/images/=\nbottom_section.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n\t =20\n    <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">CORPORATE =\nPROFILE</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/dailydouble/images/=\ndots.gif" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/dailydouble/images/clear.g=\nif" height=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>Telecommunication Products Inc (OTCBB: TCPD) is a provider of =\nhigh end digital satellite television, high-speed Wireless Internet =\nservices to the hospitality and multi-dwelling unit (MDU) marketplace. =\nIt is focused on expanding on its current 8,000 room pay per view video =\non demand product, to include services to multi-dwelling -units (MDU\'s), =\nboth to the US, and international markets. The company has partnered =\nwith Echostar, a world leading provider of programming, to deliver this =\nnext generation of home viewing and entertainment service.</p>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>THE MULTI-DWELLING UNIT MARKET.</strong></font></p>\n=20\n<p>The total number of MDUs in the United States exceeds 26 million =\nunits. The Yankee Group has estimated that the potential revenue =\nopportunity for supplying video, data and voice services to U.S. =\nresidential MDUs to be about a $200 billion annual revenue =\nopportunity.</p>\n=20\n<p>A number of factors contribute to the emergence of this enormous =\nopportunity. First, the "monopoly" providers, such as cable television =\noperators, whom have historically served this market, are using outdated =\nanalog technology for the most part. Thus, there have been limited =\ndigital cable services available to the residents living within these =\nbuildings. Second, the relationships between the property owners and =\nmanagers that control access to these properties and the monopolistic =\nsuppliers providing the service have been significantly strained over =\nthe past 15 years. Third, advancements in communications and information =\ntechnology have created an enormous demand within these properties for =\nnew state-of-the-art services, such as digital satellite television and =\nhigh-speed Internet services. Fourth, a significant regulatory shift has =\ncreated an environment where competition is fostered and encouraged.</p>\n=20\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>THE RESORT/HOSPITALITY MARKET</strong></font></p>\n\n<p>TCPD\'s wholly-owned subsidiary, The Hotel Movie Network (HMN), =\ncurrently services over 50 hotels and 8,000 rooms nationally and =\ninternationally to guests. The Company has consistent revenues from =\nthese properties and the relationships with the property owners allows =\nus to vertically integrate services to their properties. Whether is be =\ndigital cable, high speed internet services, or Wireless Fidelity =\n(Wi-Fi).</p>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGES</strong></font></p>\n\n<p>Through its acquisitions, Telpro can can supply the hardware, without =\nany downtime, to support services more than 100,000 guest rooms at =\napproximately half of the current industry average installation cost per =\nroom. Leveraging its existing assets and installation expertise, =\ndeployment time is estimated at less than 90 days from a contract =\nsignature.\nWith a typical hotel contract having a duration of five years, =\nmanagement expects to breakeven in its first year and generate =\nincreasing profits each year thereafter.</p>\n\n<p>Telpro and HMN contract directly with hotel properties (chain, =\nfranchise and independent) to operate the digital entertainment and =\nInternet systems for their properties. Company products are fully =\nintegrated with the hotel\'s Property Management (PMS) and Back Office =\nBilling Systems, which manage collection, minimize administration and =\noptimize revenue for both Telpro and their customers. Direct access to =\nsuch an intricate part of the hotel operation allows Telpro to have =\ndirect debit in the hotel accounts to insure compensation for all =\nutilized services.</p>\n\n<p>Telpro has also developed an innovative third party royalty model =\nthat ensures the Company, its partnered movie studios and client hotels =\nreceive revenues that offset their costs and provide operational =\nprofit.</p>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>MULTIFOLD GROWTH STRATEGIES</strong></font></p>\n\n<p>Telpro is embarking upon a systematic growth strategy in order to =\naccelerate revenues and achieve positive cash flows and earnings in the =\nnear future.</p>\n=20\n<p>With an established customer base of over 8,000 rooms, Telpro =\ncurrently enjoys an immediate revenue flow of $75,000 per month. The =\nCompany plans to pursue additional, complementary acquisitions in order =\nto rapidly build its customer base. <p>Telpro has signed a letter of =\nintent with In Room Video, which would add roughly 10,000 additional =\nhotel rooms, translating to approximately $100,000 more in revenues per =\nmonth.</p>\n\n<p>Concurrently, Telpro is engaging in contract negotiations for a =\nfurther 5,000 rooms that would extend Telpro\'s market share in Puerto =\nRico and the U.S. Virgin islands. These contracts consist of mainly =\nfree-to-guest or pay-per-stay services which would deliver a revenue =\nincrease of $100,000 per month upon deployment.</p>\n=20\n<p>Once it has significantly grown its customer base, Telpro plans to =\nrollout additional guest entertainment products that would create =\nincremental revenues per room, per month.</p>\n=20\n<p>To assist in its sales efforts, the Company plans to establish =\nstrategic sales partners to create an additional channel for generation =\nof sales revenue. Telpro has identified Property Management Systems =\n(PMS) Software Providers as an immediate and qualified sales channel. =\nCost of sales can be reduced as the PMS Software Providers eliminate the =\ntime-consuming sales qualification process and leverage their existing =\ncustomer base to close contracts for guest\'s entertainment.</p>\n=20\n<p>In addition to capturing share in the small-to mid-sized market for =\nits VOD services, the Company has entered the exciting, high-growth =\nmarket of wi-fi. In the fourth quarter of 2003, Telpro entered into an =\nagreement with Network Installation Corp., a total IT Solutions provider =\nthat designs, deploys and services traditional communications networks =\nas well as wireless networks and wi-fi solutions. Through this =\nrelationship, Telpro now offers its customers wi-solutions. In turn, =\nTelpro has been named the primary provider of visual technology =\nsolutions for NIC projects.</p>=20\n\n\t\t\t=09\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font>\n\t\t\t\t</td>\n            </tr>\n Prior to =\njoining Telpro, Dr. Loginov was the Lead Developer for Semantica, Ltd.; =\nhe was responsible for the implementation of accounting and business =\napplications for corporate client organizations in Germany and =\nSwitzerland.</p>\n=20\n<p><strong>Paul La Barre</strong>, <em>President-Hotel Movie =\nNetwork</em>, a wholly-owned subsidiary, brings extensive engineering =\nand cable industry experience to the Company. From 1992 to present, Mr. LaBarre has operated Coast =\nCommunication, providing engineering and consulting work.    <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" =\nface=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">\n\t\t\t\t<P><strong>CYPM, located in Seoul, South Korea, is a 3D Digital =\nAnimation Production company providing services to the television, =\ncommercial and film industries. CYPM was established on January 27, 2000 =\nand currently has approximately 24 full-time employees and 26 part-time =\nemployees.  CYPM maintains an administrative office in Toronto, =\nCanada.</strong></P>\n=20\n<P><strong>CYPM has produced award-winning CGI (computer generated =\nimage) animations with the objective of providing high-quality animation =\nTV programming and feature film for the North American market. By =\ntapping into the animation skills and competitive wages of South Korea, =\nCYPM is expecting to provide cost-effective shorts, TV series and =\nfull-length feature films for the North American TV and box-office =\nmarkets. </strong></P>\n=20\n<P><strong>CYPM has been developing projects since 1998 and is well =\npositioned to enter the North American market as a low-cost producer of =\n3D digital animation.</strong></P>\n=20\n<P><strong>CYPM currently has numerous projects in various stages of =\ndevelopment, which it expects to contribute to revenues over the next =\nseveral years.</strong></P>\n\t\t\t\t</font>\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2"><strong></strong></font>=20\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2">\n\t\t\t\t<p><strong>As recently quoted by CYPM\'s CEO, regarding their =\nJoongang acquisition, "Cyper will now be able to offer our combined =\nclients traditional 2D along with 3D animation content, enabling the =\nCompany to compete profitably with world class animators such as Pixar =\nand Disney". Cyper and Joongang subsequently agreed that a merger that =\nled to capturing significant market share would benefit and enhance =\nshareholder value.</strong></p>\n\t\t\t=09\n\n\t\t\t\t</font>\n\t\t\t\t</td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://click.upper-web-side.com/images/daily/bottom_section=\n.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n=09\n\t<table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#CC0000" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">Press Release =\n</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://click.upper-web-side.com/images/daily/dots.gif" =\nheight=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://click.upper-web-side.com/images/daily/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">\n\t\t\t\t<strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p><font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"3" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">Cyper Media contracts with Mouse to do OEM Animation from =\nJapan</font><br>\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"1" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">Wednesday February 4, 4:01 pm EST</font></p>=20\n\n<p>NEW YORK, February 4, 2004 (PRIMEZONE) -- Cyper Media, Inc. =\n(``Cyper\'\') (OTC BB: <a =\nhref=3D"http://click1.upper-web-side.com/sp/t.pl?id=3D16891:53305368" =\ntarget=3D"_blank">CYPM.OB - News</a>) announced today that they have =\nentered into a contract with Mouse Co., Ltd. ("Mouse") for several =\ndifferent animation projects in Japan. Some of the OEM productions Cyper =\nand Mouse are working on are "Godanna", "F-Zero" and "Spy Military =\nQ".</p>\n\n<p>Earnings from the animation productions will represent about Y =\n17,500,000 (USD $165,830) per month in revenue starting March 2004.</p>\n\n<p>Cyper will be doing about 50,000 animation sheets per month.<p>\n\n<p>Cyper will be working from December 18, 2003 to December 18, 2004. =\nThis contract has the option to be extended to 2 years.</p>\n\n<p>The contract gives Cyper the rights to do main production which =\nincludes animation, digital cel painting and background painting.</p>\n\n<p>Duk Jin Jang, CEO of Cyper comments, "I am pleased to work with Mouse =\non these animation productions. This contract will further show Cyper\'s =\npresence in 2D animation."</p>\n\n<p>About Mouse</p>\n\n<p>Mouse is a 2D animation company located in Tokyo, Japan.</p>\n\n<p>About Cyper Media</p>\n=20\n<p>Cyper (http://www.cypermedia.com) is a 2D/3D digital animation =\nproduction company, producing its own proprietary content and providing =\nservices to the television, commercial and film industries globally. The =\nCompany develops and produces 2D and 3D digital animation for =\ntelevision, Original Video Animation, short films, 2D and CGI feature =\nfilms, music videos and multi-media applications such as video games. =\nCyper intends to acquire business opportunities to build revenues while =\nbuilding a library of quality movies and TV series. Current Projects =\ninclude, ``The 5th Glacial Epoch,\'\' a full-length feature film with a =\ndistribution LOI signed by MGM and "OMRoid", a TV animated series that =\nhas already sold over 10,000,000 toy items. In addition, Cyper is =\nnegotiating to produce ``Hobie & Chewby\'\', a 26-episode proprietary TV =\nshow and two additional animated TV series, ``Kollang\'\' and =\n``Q-Pet.\'\'</p>\n\n<p>All forward-looking statements contained herein are deemed by the =\ncompany to be covered by and to qualify for the safe harbor protection =\nprovided by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (the =\n``1995 act\'\'). By introducing our Always On utility product lineup =\nat the early stage in the relationship between small business and ISP\'s, =\nwe can expand our presence in the market.  This venture will have =\nsignificant benefits by creating a stronger and more diversified company =\nboth for InsynQ, as well as with our new wholesale partners, thereby =\nenabling greater efficiencies, infrastructure cost savings, and more =\ndiverse products for our customers."</font></p>\n              <p><font color=3D"#666666" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif">"There are over 7,000 small to mid-size ISP\'s in =\nthe marketplace. New services will be =\nintroduced as frequently as technology advancements are introduced, =\ntherefore creating opportunity for customer up-sell."</font></p>\n              <p><font color=3D"#666666" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif"><strong>About InsynQ</strong></font></p>\n              <p><font color=3D"#666666" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif">InsynQ has been delivering outsourced software =\napplication hosting and managed IT services since 1997. The =\ncompany also offers IT and network integration consulting, multimedia =\ndevelopment, a broad range of business application services, and =\ninfrastructure management services. (Investor Relations)<br>\n              253-284-2000<br>\n              <a href=3D"mailto:ir@insynq.com">ir@insynq.com</a> <br>\n  <br>\nOR<br><br>\n              </font>InsynQ,\n              Inc. (Sales) 253-284-2000<br>\n              Sales - James Torpey<br>\n  <a href=3D"mailto:sales@insynq.com">sales@insynq.com</a></font></p>\n              <font class=3D"orange">&nbsp;</font>\n          <!--start content here-->          </td>\n        </tr>\n        <tr>\n          <td =\nbackground=3D"http://click.billionzillion.com/images/intelligent/bottom_n=\new.gif" height=3D"30">&nbsp;</td>\n        </tr>\n      </table>\n\t  <a name=3D"#about"></a>\n\t  <table cellpadding=3D"5" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFE0" width=3D"660" =\nborder=3D"0" style=3D"border-collapse: collapse">\n        <tr>\n            <td =\nbackground=3D"http://click.billionzillion.com/images/intelligent/top_new.=\ngif" height=3D"30">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFE0" =\nsize=3D"2" face=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">About =\nCompany</font></strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href=3D"#top"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://click.billionzillion.com/images/intelligent/top_arrow.gif" =\nborder=3D"0" height=3D"10" width=3D"18"></a></td>\n        </tr>\n        <tr>\n            <td valign=3D"top" width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFD" =\nborder=3D"0" style=3D"border-collapse: collapse">\n              <!--start content here-->\n              <font color=3D"#666666" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif">\n\t\t\t  <p><strong>ASP Industry </strong><br>\n                <strong>What Is An Application Service Provider (ASP) =\n</strong><br>\nAn application service provider (ASP) is a company that offers =\nindividuals or groups access over the Internet to software applications =\nand related services that would otherwise have to be located in their =\nown personal or enterprise computers. ASP services are expected to =\nbecome an important alternative, not only for smaller companies with low =\nbudgets for information technology, but also for larger companies as a =\nform of outsourcing and for many services for individuals as well. </p>\n\n              <p>Early applications include: </p>\n              <ul>\n                <li>Remote access serving for the users of an enterprise =\n</li>\n                <li>An off-premises local area network to which mobile =\nusers can be connected, with a common file server </li>\n                <li>Specialized applications that would be expensive to =\ninstall and maintain within your own company or on your own computer =\n</li>\n              </ul>\n              <p>While ASPs are forecast to provide applications and =\nservices to small enterprises and individuals on a pay-per-use or yearly =\nlicense basis, larger corporations are essentially providing their own =\nASP service in-house, moving applications off personal computers and =\nputting them on a special kind of application server that is designed to =\nhandle the stripped-down kind of thin client workstation. This allows an =\nenterprise to reassert the central control over application cost and =\nusage that corporations formerly had in the period prior to the advent =\nof the PC. Microsoft&#39;s Terminal Server product and Citrix&#39;s =\nWinFrame products are leading thin-client application server products. =\n</p>\n              <p><strong>MSP Industry </strong></p>\n              <p><strong>What is an MSP? </strong><br>\n  The managed service provider (MSP) phenomenon is between 18 and 24 =\nmonths old and is attracting a lot of attention from potential users and =\nservice providers wanting to add value. But different providers define =\nit different ways, and service offerings range from the very limited to =\nthe very broad. <br>\n  <br>\n  A managed service provider delivers aspects of outsourced IT =\noperations, usually via an IP network. All MSPs remotely manage network =\ninfrastructure on an ongoing basis, while some extend their offerings to =\nprovide and manage application infrastructure. Note: Some MSPs refer to =\nthemselves as &#39;management service providers. </p>\n              <p><strong>Three main types of MSP </strong><br>\n  In today&#39;s market, three main types of MSP can be distinguished. =\nThey differ in terms of: </p>\n              <ul>\n                <li>The range of services offered </li>\n                <li>The amount of responsibility they take for a =\nclient&#39;s business </li>\n                <li>Scope - that is, the size of the MSP and the size of =\ntheir target customer </li>\n              </ul>\n              <p><strong>The low level - pure-play MSPs </strong><br>\n  This group of MSPs describe themselves as &#39;management service =\nproviders&#39;, not &#39;managed service providers&#39;. Many of the =\nmembers of the year-old MSP Association fall into this category. The =\ndefining principle here is that these MSPs assist client companies in =\nmanaging network infrastructure and limit themselves primarily to =\nmonitoring the performance of the network and of applications running =\nover the network. They deliver services remotely via an IP network, =\nsometimes by gathering data from a client&#39;s site via a networked =\nserver placed on site. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Range of services </strong><br>\n  Watching uptime, performance and availability are the central value =\npropositions of this type of MSP, although many in this category are =\nexpanding into extended infrastructure services, such as security, =\nstorage and testing. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Level of responsibility </strong><br>\n  This type of MSP takes little, if any, responsibility for a =\nclient&#39;s business. If it offers a service-level agreement, it is =\nlikely to be for the uptime of its own monitoring process, not for the =\nclient&#39;s website. Its activities might be limited to reporting and =\nalerts if a website experiences problems, or might extend to generating =\nand tracking problem reports. If it extends its offerings to include =\nsecurity and storage, its responsibility level may increase accordingly. =\n<br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Scope </strong><br>\n  MSPs at this level tend to be small (50-300 employees). Their clients =\nwill be SMEs with IT departments that are either understaffed, taken up =\nwith major projects, or focused on non-infrastructure core competencies. =\nClients tend to engage a low-level MSP for one aspect of infrastructure =\nmonitoring; if the relationship develops satisfactorily, they will then =\nadd additional services over time. <br>\n  <br>\n  This level of MSP is attempting to make MSP work as a business model, =\nwhich will have short-term success at best. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>The mid-level - MSP as a value-added service </strong><br>\n  Mid-level MSPs tend to describe themselves as &#39;managed service =\nproviders&#39; and to offer a broader range of services that take =\ngreater responsibility for a client&#39;s business. </p>\n              <p><strong>Range of services </strong><br>\n  These MSPs may move beyond performance monitoring and reporting to =\nsoftware patches, installation and upgrades, and application =\ninfrastructure provision, which require them to be proficient in web =\napplication servers. An MSP at this level will take pride in offering as =\nwide a range of services as possible, seeing this as a differentiator. =\n<br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Level of responsibility </strong><br>\n  Mid-level MSPs also differentiate themselves by assuming greater =\nresponsibility for the functioning of a client&#39;s business. If a site =\ngoes down, they will do more than notification - they will work with the =\nclient to restore function. Service-level agreements reflect this level =\nof responsibility. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Scope </strong><br>\n  MSPs at this level can be large, as managed service will be folded in =\nto other service offerings, such as web hosting or network provision. =\nThey target the Fortune 500 or 1,000 enterprise as a customer, although =\nmany also serve medium-sized clicks-and-mortar companies. <br>\n  <br>\n  Web-hosting providers such as Digex offer MSP at this level as a =\nvalue-added service to their core service provision, which is hosting =\nwebsites. Major Telcos such as Cable &amp; Wireless and France Telecom =\n(via Equant and Global One) offer MSP as well. Loudcloud is probably the =\nbest-known example of a pure-play MSP that has grown its business =\nsuccessfully in past years, although it is currently struggling to make =\nthe concept work in an inhospitable economy. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>The high level - outsourcing IT operations </strong><br>\n  These MSPs undertake to allow clients to outsource their entire IT =\noperation, if desired - truly one-stop shopping. They can also provide =\nlower levels of service, like a mid-level MSP. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Range of services </strong><br>\n  MSPs at this level offer a full range of traditional managed service =\nand add aspects of application handling, such as integration and even =\napplication hosting, which can be defined as &#39;one-to-one remote =\ncustom outsourcing of applications. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Level of responsibility </strong><br>\n  Service-level agreements in this segment will be customized to reflect =\ndiffering levels of responsibility available to clients, depending on =\nhow much they want and are willing to pay. This type of MSP can be the =\nmythical xSP that shapes the technological identity of the client, =\nchoosing its hardware, storage, level of security and packaged =\napplication suites. <br>\n  <br>\n  <strong>Scope </strong><br>\n  Small and large providers co-exist in this space, serving different =\nconstituencies. Systems integrators and consultancies play here. =\nBoutique shops serve SMEs, and large providers such as EDS, IBM Global =\nServices and Pricewaterhouse Coopers serve large multinational =\ncorporations and, increasingly, medium-sized enterprises - competing =\nwith smaller shops in these cases. </p>\n              <p><strong>Management Team: </strong></p>\n              <p>InsynQ&#39;s executive management team is responsible =\nfor forming strategy and direction for the Company, as well as meeting =\nrevenue and profitability goals. <br>\n                <br>\n                <br>\n                <strong>John P. Gorst </strong>- <em><strong>Chairman, =\nPresident and Chief Executive Officer </strong></em><br>\n                John P. style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">About =\nCINM</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" =\nsize=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>CINM is a wireless services company and creator of =\nPocketCinema&#8482; multimedia.   The Hollywood-based studio produces =\ndownloadable video, applications and graphics for a global audience. =\nCINM was founded by filmmaker James F. Robinson in 1999 and is based at =\nthe Los Angeles Center Studio complex in Los Angeles.</p>\n\n<p>CINM owns what is believed to be the world\'s largest library of =\nmultimedia & graphic content for mobile devices, with a focus on global =\ndistribution of advanced mobile data services. Mobile data services are =\nkey to network operators as they work to capitalize on new high-speed =\nnetworks and the current boom in color mobile phones sales. CINM =\nproduces their multimedia content in a wide variety of mobile formats, =\nto optimize the user experience and value. The content is customized for =\nNokia, Motorola, Seimens, Sony Ericsson, Samsung, LG and other popular =\nhandsets.</p>\n\n\n\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>The Market for Mobile Multimedia and Value Added =\nServices</strong></font></p>\n\n<p>The telecom industry has invested heavily in high-speed wireless =\n(cellular) networks, and in the sales and marketing of color multimedia =\nmobile phones. These next-generation mobile phones are experiencing =\nimpressive growth in mature markets as users "trade up" to color =\nterminals and add services like picture messaging and video downloads.  =\nIn addition, developing territories such as Eastern Europe, India and =\nChina are adding first-time mobile subscribers in dramatic numbers, many =\nof whom are starting out with multimedia enabled phones.</p>=20\n\n<p>These new mobile phones are important to mobile network operators =\n(carriers) in that they facilitate in the development of data sales =\ngrowth to complement a mature voice communication business.  Mobile =\nphone manufacturers such as Nokia, Sony Ericsson, Panasonic, Seimens, =\nMotorola and Samsung, are betting heavily on consumer&#39s migration to =\nMultimedia Messaging Services (MMS) and color phones as the standard, in =\nmuch the same way as color screened PCs are the standard today.</p>=20\n\n<p>Forrester Research predicted Multimedia Messaging Services (MMS) =\nrevenues of USD $2 billion in 2003 and USD $48 billion in 2006. These =\nnew graphics delivery systems allow users to enhance their text messages =\nwith graphics, animations, small video clips and audio.  Juniper =\nResearch has estimated that MMS revenues will reach USD $8.3 billion by =\n2004. USD $5.6bn is expected to be generated by third party content =\ndelivery of the kind of content the Company produces.</p>\n\n<p>According to Industry estimates, there are currently more than 1.3 =\nbillion mobile phone subscribers globally.</p>\n\n</strong></font></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n\t    <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">Press Release =\n</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" =\nsize=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>A  relatively small percentage penetration rate could possibly =\ntranslate into Millions of Dollars of revenue to CINM.</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font>\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"3" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>CINEMAELECTRIC, INC. LAUNCHES POCKETCINEMA&#8482; VIDEO ON MOBILE =\nPHONES WITH T-MOBILE EUROPE 40+ MILLION SUBSCRIBERS</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font>\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif">\n\t\t\t\t<p>Hollywood, California ? March 15, 2004. <span =\nclass=3D"style1">CINEMAELECTRIC, INC.</span> (OTCBB: CINM) announces the =\nlaunch of its PocketCinema&#8482; mobile video content offerings via =\nleading operator T-MOBILE in the UK, Germany, Netherlands, Austria and =\nCzech Republic, a total market of over 40 million subscribers.</p>  =20\n\n<p>CinemaElectric is a Hollywood-based producer of mobile entertainment =\nand services.  PocketCinema&#8482; is a downloadable motion picture that =\ncan be played on many Nokia, Sony Ericsson, Siemens and other mobile =\nphone terminals. The deal includes all current CinemaElectric video =\ncontent lines, such as ACTION SPORTS, ELECTRIC CATWALK, MOVIE MESSAGES =\nand HOLLYWOOD GIRLS.  The video is downloaded via T-Mobile\'s "t-zones" =\nservice and can be collected and re-played on select GPRS handsets, and =\nshared with friends via MMS or email.  Each PocketCinema&#8482; file is =\nunder 90kb in size.  The extremely small motion picture files size is =\nproduced using CinemaElectric\'s proprietary Dense Media Format&#8482; =\ntechnology.  The motion pictures are from 10 to 25 seconds in length, =\ndepending on subject matter and frame rate. Video prices are currently =\nGBP 2.45 in the UK per download and EURO 1.99 in Germany.  Mobile video =\nphones are in early stages of adoption but sales are growing rapidly and =\nwill further accelerate as consumers continue to upgrade old mobile =\nphones for new multimedia color terminals.</p>\n\n<p>CinemaElectric owns what is believed to be the world\'s largest =\nlibrary of formatted multimedia and video content for mobile devices. =\nThe company has a special focus on video content for mobile phone =\nplayback, both in the current 2.5G environments and into advanced, =\nhigh-speed 3G networks.</p>=20\n\n<p>ABOUT CINEMA ELECTRIC: CinemaElectric is a wireless services company =\nand a leading provider of multimedia entertainment for mobile devices. =\nThe Hollywood-based studio\'s product is currently distributed in more =\nthan 35 countries in five continents.<p>\n\n<p>Website:  <a =\nhref=3D"http://click1.upper-web-side.com/sp/t.pl?id=3D18758:53305368">htt=\np://www.CinemaElectric.com</a></p>\n\n<p>ABOUT T-MOBILE: T-Mobile International is one of the world\'s leading =\ncompanies in mobile communications. As one of Deutsche Telekom\'s four =\nstrategic divisions, T-Mobile concentrates on the most dynamic markets =\nin Europe and the United States. By the end of the second quarter 2003, =\nmore than 87 million people were using the mobile communications =\nservices provided by companies in which T-Mobile or Deutsche Telekom =\nhave a majority or minority stake. </p>\n\n<p>&quot;SAFE HARBOR&quot; STATEMENT</p>\n\n<p>This Press Release may contain forward-looking statements, including =\nthe Company\'s beliefs about its business prospects and future results of =\noperations.  These statements involve risks and uncertainties. In =\naddition, the factors underlying Company forecasts are dynamic and =\nsubject to change and therefore those forecasts speak only as of the =\ndate they are given.</p>=20\n<p>Contact: Yui Yamane<br>\nCinemaElectric, Inc.<br>\nEmail: <a =\nhref=3D"mailto:Investors@CinemaElectric.com">Investors@CinemaElectric.com=\n</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</font>\n\t\t\t</td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n\t    <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>CINM&#39s Global Distribution =\nNetwork</strong></font></p>\n\n<p>CINM has built what is believed to be the mobile industry&#39s =\nlargest multimedia distribution network. In Q1, 2004, the Company&#39s =\ncontent and services are expected to be actively distributed in 5 =\ncontinents and 36 countries (USA, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, UK, Ireland, =\nHolland, Belgium, France, Germany, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, =\nLatvia, Estonia, Lithuania, Czech Republic, Slovenia, Croatia, Italy, =\nFrance, Spain, Portugal, Israel, Kuwait, India, Singapore, Philippines, =\nThailand, Malaysia, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Australia and New =\nZealand).</p>=20\n\n<p>Operators expected to be offering CINM content in Q1, 2004 include =\nAT&T Wireless, mmO2, Sprint PCS, T-Mobile, Nextel, KPN, China Mobile, =\nOrange, Vodafone, CSL Hong Kong, Telefonica Moviles, TIM and many =\nothers.  Many of these distributors first became active for the Company =\nin Q4, 2003.</p>\n\n<p>CINM&#39s distribution network include the top operators, resellers =\nand manufacturers in the mobile industry, including Nokia (Global), Sony =\nEricsson (Europe), Mforma (Global), Jamba (Europe), Musiwave (Europe & =\nAustralia), Wireless Entertainment Services (Europe), Orange Gum (Asia), =\nSonera Zed (Europe and Asia), End2End (Europe), Buongiorno (Global) and =\nothers.</p>\n\n<p>Revenue & Financial Plans (excerpts from 3/13/04 news release)</p>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#009966" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>CINM&#39s Potential</strong></font></p>=20\n\n<p>&#8220;Based on the continued growth of color multimedia mobile phone =\nsales, and the continuing advancement of billing and delivery technology =\nwithin the mobile industry, the Company makes the following =\nestimates:</p>=20\n\n<p>The Company anticipates total mobile multimedia (graphics, video and =\naudio files) revenues (including content and data fees) to reach $300 =\nmillion at the end of 2004. Out of that, 15% of the revenues ($45m) are =\nexpected to be content fees for services such as 3rd party audio, videos =\nand graphics, of which approximately 20% of that amount will be paid to =\ncontent owners ($9m). The Company expects to capture up to 6% of this =\nmarket with its video, graphics and application services, despite the =\nexpectation that the majority of revenue will be dedicated to audio =\ndownloads (audio ringers).</p>=20\n\n<p>Mobile multimedia revenues for 2005 are anticipated to pass the one =\nbillion dollar mark catering to an audience of 175m global users. The =\nCompany anticipates capturing up to 7% of this market based on the =\nleverage of its distribution network to attract new popular brands, and =\nthe acquisition of companies with complementary technology and business =\nmodels, provided the Company can raise the required expansion =\ncapital.</p>=20\n\n<p>The Company anticipates the market will grow by the end of 2006 to =\nmore than 250 million "mobile multimedia subscribers" and that graphics, =\nmotion MMS and video will dominate the industry. The Company anticipates =\ntotal mobile multimedia (graphics, video and audio files) revenues in =\n2006 to reach $2.8 billion as usage becomes commonplace and sponsored =\nmobile multimedia dominates over the pay-per-download model. Out of a =\ntotal global market of $2.1b, it is anticipated that 35% ($735m) will be =\ncontent services revenue, of which approximately 20% will be paid to =\ncontent owners ($147m). The Company anticipates capturing up to 8% of =\nthis market in 2006.</p>=20\n\n<p>These projections are dependent on the company raising significant =\noperating capital in 2004 for marketing and sales expenses, expanded =\nproduction, brand licensing, and acquisitions.&#8221;</p>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font>             =20\n\n\t\t\t</td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n=09\n\t <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2">Summary</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>CINM was down 50% on Friday on no negative news whatsoever. ("TIC") (OTC BB =\n"TIDC") is pleased to announce its revenue guidance for fiscal 2004.  =\nThe overall effect will increase the projected revenues of TIC couple =\nwith targeted acquisitions to approximately $30 million for fiscal year =\n2004 and $.16 per share in overall earnings.               TIC is =\ncompleting the final phase of its financing, TIC had secured funding for =\n$1,500,000 previously, but choose to accept only $300,000 and placed the =\nbalance on hold until the outcome of its pending arbitration case.  </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Since the settlement TIC has been working on securing and additional =\n$1,000,000 in financing on top of the $300,000 it has already received.  =\nOriginally TIC was seeking funding up to $1,700,000, but since the =\nreduction of the purchase price TIC does not need to raise as much money =\nnow nor cause further dilution to the shareholders.  The $1,000,000 will =\nbe used to will be used to pay down debt and restructure credit lines =\nwithin its recent acquisition of Total Identity Group. The restructuring =\nwill enable TIG to begin bidding on projects that require certain bond =\nrequirements that were not being met prior to the recent purchase. TIG =\nhas the historically bid on approximately $20 million of new business =\neach year and has capture approximately 10% of the projects it bids on.  =\n  </p>\n<p>Philip Mistretta, president of TIC, stated "The additional capital =\nwill assist TIC in making its subsidiary Total Identity Systems ("TIS") =\na financially responsible company and will enable TIS to begin bidding =\non new projects they have not been able to for the past year.   This =\nwill result in higher profits margins and earnings per share for TIC =\nshareholders".  </p>\n<p>About TIC </p>\n<p>TIC is developing opportunities within the $13 billion signage =\nindustry with the goal of becoming the place for corporate America to go =\nfor their custom sign needs.  <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                    <strong>\n\n               \t\t<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif" size=3D"2">\n\n<p>This News Release Could Potentially have a positive impact on TIDC in =\nthe short-term, by possibly increasing EPS greater than the already =\nforecasted $0.13 per share in 2004. Reason being, by paying off =\nshort-term obligations could save TIDC in the long-term.</p>\n\n<p>Philip Mistretta, president of TIC, stated, "TIC is pleased to have =\nsettled this matter without a long arbitration process for the benefit =\nof the shareholders. We have significantly reduced our investment in =\nTIS, and with the matter settled, we can now focus our attention on =\ngrowing TIS through internal growth and other acquisitions we\'ve =\nidentified that will complement our business strategy." </p>\n\n<p>Press Release</p>\n\n</font>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"4">Total Identity Corp. Saves $700,000, Drops Arbitration =\nCase</font></p>\n\n\n</strong>\n\n<p><font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"1">March 05, 2004 4:05:00 PM ET</font></p>\n\n                    <strong>\n\n               \t\t<font color=3D"#333333" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif" size=3D"2">\n\n<p>ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 5 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Total Identity =\nCorp. (OTC Bulletin Board: TIDC) ("TIC") announced today that it has =\nreached a settlement with Robert J. David ("Seller") regarding the =\npurchase of Total Identity Systems, Inc. ("TIS")\n(<a =\nhref=3D"http://click1.upper-web-side.com/sp/t.pl?id=3D18391:53305368">www=\n.totalidentity.com</a>) and that it has cancelled its previously =\nannounced arbitration. The settlement reduces the purchase price from =\n$1.8 million to $1.1 million, saving TIC $700,000 in cash. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>TIC has been able to make changes to the original agreements that =\nfavor the shareholders of TIC. The balance owed for the purchase of TIS =\nis $875,000, of which $475,000 will be invested into TIS to be used to =\npay down short-term loans and the working credit line. The remaining =\n$400,000, which is payable to the Seller, is structured in quarterly =\npayments to begin January 2005. TIC also re-wrote the lease for 10 years =\nat the same rate with no increase in rent, but TIC has the right to =\npurchase the building at fair market value to be determined by three =\nindependent appraisers at the end of five years and removed the $100,000 =\nbuilding improvement clause to trigger the right to purchase. </p>\n<p>TIC has an obligation to invest only $475,000 to cover the purchase =\nof the company. The quarterly payments to the Seller will come from cash =\nflow, which basically allows TIC to purchase a company that had revenues =\nof over $9 million for fiscal year 2003 and was profitable for a total =\nof $700,000 in cash. </p>\n<p>TIC originally purchased TIS for $1.8 million on October 13, 2003, at =\nwhich time TIC paid $150,000 and received a credit of $75,000 for legal =\nand accounting expenses, leaving a balance owed of $775,000 to be paid =\nin installments with the final payment to be made December 31, 2003. TIC =\ndiscovered during its audit of TIS material misrepresentations and =\ninaccuracies and informed the Seller that TIC was going to pursue its =\nrights under the Agreement to protect the TIC shareholders. TIC filed an =\n8K on December 9, 2003 announcing that it was filing an arbitration case =\nagainst the Seller to seek damages from the misrepresentations on behalf =\nof the shareholders. TIC immediately ceased making additional payment to =\nthe Seller and began working on reducing the purchase price to offset =\nthe differences uncovered by the auditors. </p>\n<p>Philip Mistretta, president of TIC, stated, "TIC is pleased to have =\nsettled this matter without a long arbitration process for the benefit =\nof the shareholders. We have significantly reduced our investment in =\nTIS, and with the matter settled, we can now focus our attention on =\ngrowing TIS through internal growth and other acquisitions we\'ve =\nidentified that will complement our business strategy." </p>\n<p>About TIC </p>\n<p>TIC is developing opportunities within the $13 billion signage =\nindustry with the goal of becoming the place for corporate America to go =\nfor their custom sign needs. TIC initial plans are to acquire various =\nplants located on the Eastern seaboard, giving TIC a strong presence =\nalong the Eastcoast through the Midwest. TIC is looking at various sign =\ncompanies that will allow TIC to absorb their operations and cut out all =\nupper management, and in some cases, shift operations to its existing =\nplant that has the capacity to generate $40 million a year in revenues =\nby adding additional shifts. </p>\n<p>Certain information contained in this news release may include =\nforward- looking statements within the meaning of Section 27A of the =\nSecurities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of =\n1934. While these statements are made to convey the company\'s progress, =\nbusiness opportunities and growth prospects, readers are cautioned that =\nsuch forward-looking statements represent management\'s opinion. Actual =\ncompany results may differ materially from those described. The =\ncompany\'s operations and business prospects are always subject to risk =\nand uncertainties. A more extensive listing of risks and factors that =\nmay affect the business prospects of the company and cause actual =\nresults to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking =\nstatements can be found in the reports and other documents filed by the =\ncompany with the Securities and Exchange Commission. </p>\n<p>&#169; 2004 PRNewswire </p>\n\n\n</font>\n\n\n</strong></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n\n\t<table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3D"2">Company =\nProfile</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" =\nsize=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t</strong></font><p><font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif"><strong>TIDC is a custom manufacturer of LED =\ndisplays, custom signs and awnings, headquartered in Wellington, FL. =\nTIDC is in the process of making several acquisitions that will make it =\nvertically integrated with in-house marketing, sales, design, =\nengineering, manufacturing, and installation =\ncapabilities.</strong></font></p>\n\n                <font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, =\nHelvetica, sans-serif"><strong><p>TIDC is pursuing several acquisitions =\nwith the intent of achieving annual revenues of $25 Million Dollars by =\nthe end of 2004 with a pre-tax margin of fifteen percent. The next goal =\nwould be to increase sales through acquisition and organic growth to $50 =\nMillion Dollars by the end of 2006 with a pre-tax margin of seventeen =\npercent. The signage industry is over $13 Billion Dollars in annual =\nrevenues and is highly fragmented.</p>\n\n<p>The core manufacturing business consists of custom on-premise =\nidentity products. Through the acquisition of Total Identity Group "TIG" =\nTIDC has added neon, channel letters, cabinet signs, commercial awnings =\nto TIC?s exisiting LED Displays. TIG has had great success in recent =\nyears in designing and manufacturing highly custom "theme" signage for =\ncustomers such as Hard Rock Cafe, Gibson Guitars, and Walt Disney World. =\nAdditionally, TIG added manufacturing capabilities for interior/ADA =\nsigns in 1997, and digital printing in 1999.</p>\n\n<p>TIG has had steady revenue growth of approximately 25% per year, with =\nsimilar increases in profits. This growth is attributed to many factors, =\nincluding a highly skilled and experienced manufacturing staff, strong =\nfiscal management, and aggressive and disciplined sales and marketing =\nteam. The addition of essential experienced management in manufacturing =\nand finance, a new location, upgraded equipment, and a strong economy, =\nthe resulting mix was a recipe for growth and success. Despite a drop in =\nrevenue in FY2000, it was a year of focus, planning, consolidation, and =\ntraining in order to position Total Identity Corp. for planned, =\nsustainable growth over the next five years and beyond.</p>\n\n<p>TIG operates in a 85,000 square foot facility in Rochester NY with 85 =\nemployees. TIG has 12 sales people located in key regions and will be =\nadding 5 other regions over the next twelve months. TIG handles many =\nnational and regional accounts and has a separate sewing division used =\nfor military and governmental applications. This division makes =\nstrapping that can only be purchased directly from them and they also =\nmake the cover that wraps the Space Shuttle prior to being moved out on =\nthe launch pad. TIG enjoys a solid reputation that has been built up =\nover 80 years of being in business.</p>\n\t\t\t\t </strong></font></td>\n            </tr>\n        </table></td>\n      </tr>\n\t  <tr><td><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"10" width=3D"1"></td>\n\t  </tr>\n      <tr>\n         <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/bottom_s=\nection.jpg" height=3D"20">&nbsp;</td>\n      </tr>\n    </table>\n\n\t <table width=3D"660" style=3D"border-collapse:collapse" =\ncellpadding=3D"0">\n\t<!--section-->\n      <tr><!--top-->\n        <td bgcolor=3D"#009966" valign=3D"middle" =\nheight=3D"20">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong><font color=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nface=3D"Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" =\nsize=3D"2">Summary</font></strong></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td =\nbackground=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/dots.gif=\n" height=3D"1"><img =\nsrc=3D"http://images.upper-web-side.com/images/Dailygreen/clear.gif" =\nheight=3D"1" width=3D"1"></td>\n      </tr>\n      <tr>\n        <td width=3D"660" bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF" =\nstyle=3D"border-collapse:collapse">\n          <table width=3D"100%"  border=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0" =\ncellpadding=3D"5">\n            <tr>\n              <td valign=3D"top">\n                <!--start content here-->\n\t\t\t\t<font color=3D"#333333" size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial, Helvetica, =\nsans-serif"><strong>\n\t\t\t\t<p>TIDC is Forecasting that they Will Generate $25Million Dollars in =\nRevenue and $0.13 per share I earnings for 2004. TMXT signed letters of intents for =\norders totaling=20\n$3 million dollars.</p></strong>\n\n<p><font size=3D"+1"><strong>Trans Max Technologies, Inc. Announces =\nLetter of Intent for $2,000,000 from a Major Motorcycle Aftermarket =\nVendor</strong></font></p>\n=20\n<p>RONKONKOMA, NY: March 29, 2004; Perma-Tune Electronics, Inc., a =\nwholly-owned subsidiary of Trans Max Technologies, Inc., (OTCBB:TMXT), =\ntoday announced the signing of a Letter of Intent with a Major =\nMotorcycle Aftermarket Vendor to distribute Plasmatronics\' (a division =\nof Perma-Tune Electronics, Inc.) Plasma Drive Ignition System.  The =\nLetter of Intent will be converted to an order within approximately 45 =\ndays. The Letter of Intent is for a minimum of 2,000 units and =\nrepresents sales of approximately $2,000,000.</p>=20\n\n<p>The Motorcycle Aftermarket Vendor will be purchasing specially =\nconfigured and manufactured Plasma Drive Ignition Systems. The Plasma =\nDrive Ignition system is a new kind of ignition that can either be used =\nby Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEM) or aftermarket vendors.  Tests =\nshow significant increases in fuel mileage and an increase in horsepower =\nand reducing harmful emissions.  This product is currently in =\nproduction.</p>  =20\n\n<p>Said Lonnie Lenarduzzi, President and Chief Scientist for =\nPlasmatronics, a division of Perma-Tune Electronics, Inc., "To =\nunderstand what we\'ve done with the Plasma Drive Ignition, you must =\nthrow out everything you knew about motorcycle ignition. This =\nrevolutionary compact motorcycle ignition system is a completely new way =\nof achieving incredibly efficient combustion. Using never-before =\nexploited principles of physics, the PDI produces a cleaner burn than =\never before possible, converting nearly all available fuel, whatever it =\nmay be, to torque. This process results in a thrilling, measurable =\nincrease in performance, dramatically better fuel economy and as a =\nresult, reduced emissions."</p>=20\n\n<p>Trans Max Technologies, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiary =\nPerma-Tune Electronics, Inc. through its Plasmatronics division is a =\ndevelopmental Company engaged in the automotive and marine electronics =\nindustry and has several cutting edge products that were recently =\nintroduced at the Miami International Boat Show.
